article.title: The splashback radius of halos from particle dynamics. II. Dependence on mass, accretion rate, redshift, and cosmology

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the comparison of orange and white circles in Figure 1 primarily illustrate?
choices: The distribution of halo masses in the simulation.
The difference between subhalos and host halos.
The significant size difference between virial radii and splashback radii.
The accuracy of the GOTETRA code in visualizing density fields.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the tail towards positive values in the distribution of Msp/M200m, particularly evident for higher percentiles, most likely indicate?
choices: Errors in the SPARTA algorithm when analyzing high-mass halos.
The influence of large subhalos that have entered the halo but not yet significantly impacted Rsp.
A breakdown of the log-normal function for describing the mass distribution at high percentiles.
The impact of redshift on the mass distribution of halos at fixed accretion rate.

multiple_choice_question.text: What key observation from Figure 4 supports the idea that Rsp depends on Ωm rather than redshift (z) directly?
choices: The converging Γ-Rsp relation at higher redshifts (z ≥ 2) where Ωm ≈ 1.
The significant variation in the Γ-Rsp relation for different peak height bins.
The clear distinction between the low-mass and high-mass halo relations.
The increasing trend of the Γ-Rsp relation with redshift at fixed halo mass.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 6 explores the effect of using different definitions of Rsp based on the percentile of the apocenter distribution. What is the primary implication of using higher percentiles?
choices: The normalization of the Γ-Rsp curves decreases.
The relation between Γ-Rsp becomes less sensitive to redshift.
Higher percentiles lead to increasingly larger values of Rsp.
The scatter in the Γ-Rsp relation significantly decreases.
